en: Interview with Brandon Matheny, professor with the Ecology and Evolutionary Biology department of UT. Matheny discusses the effects of the fire upon fungi of the reason, particularly how it allows certain species to fruit and spread. He also touches upon the effects that climate change is having upon the region. This is a representative quote from the interview: "I was seeing some of the same fungi in this burn here in the Southeast as I had seen out west and read about being reported in Europe."

Interview with Brandon Matheny, 2019-11-07 -- Great Smoky Mountains National Park
Can you state your name and tell us how long you have lived in Knoxville and east Tennessee?
Can you tell me about your career path and role here at the University of Tennessee?
So you moved to Knoxville when you joined UT?
What are some of your personal interests, or community involvement in the area?
What was the focus of your research prior to the wildfires in 2016?
What do you remember from the time leading up to the wildfires?
At what point did you know that the wildfires were impacting your research, or would provide a research opportunity?
Was your team mostly from UT and the area, or were they from all over the country?
What was it like going into the park to conduct fieldwork after the fire? How was it different than in the past?
What were the similarities and differences between your fieldwork here and other locations you've worked in after fires?
What was the focus and the methodology of this research project in Gatlinburg?
What were the methodologies you used? What did the fieldwork look like?
Has the project continued to evolve and develop as it has continued?
Are there ways you see to build upon this research?
What do you consider to be the public impacts of your research?
Is there anything else that you would like to share?
Did you ever envision that something like this fire could've happened here, and could it happen again?

seo.title: Interview with Brandon Matheny, 2019-11-07 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
